message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about tidal energy. Tidal motion can be harnessed to generate electricity by activating turbines on shore. As the tide rises and falls, the movement of the water turns the turbines, which then produce electricity. Option (B) is unrelated to the practical use of tidal motion. Option (C) describes the natural phenomenon of waves crashing against rocks, but doesn't explain how it can be used. Option (D) is unrelated to tidal motion and the generation of electricity.

This question requires basic knowledge about tidal energy. Tidal motion refers to the rise and fall of ocean tides, which can be harnessed to generate electricity. Turbines can be placed in the path of the tidal flow to capture the kinetic energy and convert it into electrical energy. Option (B) is a metaphorical statement and not related to the use of tidal motion. Option (C) describes the natural phenomenon of wave crashing on rocks, but it does not involve the utilization of tidal motion. Option (D) is unrelated to tidal motion and refers to lighting a dark pathway using external sources of light.
